Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Low-cost and high-durability fuel cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the commercialization feasibility of a fuel cell technology to help fuel cell manufacturers solve the problem of high loading of platinum group metal catalysts. Fuel cells address the increasing societal interest and market needs in sustainable and clean energy sources as substitutes for fossil fuels, and the reduction of on-road and off-road transportation emissions. The technology will benefit the fuel cell stack or parts manufacturers who currently suffers from high manufacturing costs associated with high-cost of catalyst materials and short lifetime of fuel cell operation. The technology also will have the potential to benefit the agriculture drone manufacturers seeking alternative lightweight, highly-efficient energy package that provides long flight duration and low/zero pollution. The global fuel cell market will grow at an CAGR of about 21% to hit about 12 billion US dollars by 2026. Fuel cell-based hybrid systems are forecast to reach 46 billion US dollars. The customer discovery will identify the market needs, explore technology licensing opportunities, and develop commercialization plans. The project also will train students and researchers to better prepare to pursue entrepreneurship in technology commercialization.

This I-Corps project will focus on customer discovery to identify the market opportunity, explore entrepreneurship, and develop the business model centering on the new fuel cell technology. The fuel cell technology has the potential to address some of the challenges in the existing market in terms of customer needs arising from specific requirement to provide alternative energy storage and conversion modules that effectively manage the energy consumption, clean environment and zero pollution as well as high energy efficiency for residential use. The high cost associated with catalyst materials in the total manufacturing cost and the poor durability of existing catalysts constitute the major barrier to the mass production and application. The fuel cell technology in this project will overcome these barriers by using ultralow loading of platinum group metal catalysts and effective membrane electrode assembly to provide a low cost and high durability conversion system for fuel cell manufacturers and energy storage and conversion facilities. A minimum viable prototype demonstration of fuel cell modules also will be part of the technology development roadmap.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Binghamton
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This I-Corps project has aimed at training students and researchers as entrepreneurs in technology commercialization by focusing on determining the commercialization feasibility of a new catalyst technology in the market of fuel cells.  Like batteries, hydrogen fuel produced from renewable solar, wind, and biomass can be stored for conversion by fuel cells. Hydrogen fuel cells represents highly efficient power with zero emission and substantial energy. There is an increasing societal need of clean and sustainable energy for reduction of greenhouse gases, which constitutes the global drive for solar and wind production of electricity, battery storage, and hydrogen economy. Automotive industry has been leading the way to push fuel cell-drive vehicles in the market.  The mass commercialization of fuel cells will accelerate sustainable and clean energy sources as substitutes for fossil fuels and the reduction of transportation emissions.   The global fuel cell market is predicted to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 21%. With US government emphasis on clean and sustainable energy, a huge increase of the fuel cell market size is expected alongside with the surge of solar and wind energies.  Currently, the high catalyst cost and poor durability performance constitute two major areas of technical challenges for mass commercialization of fuel cells. The catalyst cost accounts for 40?50 % of the total manufacturing cost in fuel cell stacks.  The pain point can be addressed by 50% or more reduction of catalysts materials in existing fuel cell systems in comparison with the bottleneck up to 25 % reduction, and enhanced durability of catalysts in fuel cell performance.   Commercialization of the new catalyst technology offers an opportunity to meet the increasing demand for fuel cells by supplying high-performance catalysts for fuel cell manufacturers at low cost.  This project has obtained information on the drivers in the targeted market, the value proposition specific to customer segments, the cost breakdown in the manufacturing process, the decision-making process in adopting new technologies in the manufacturing and product ecosystem. A key outcome of this project is the new insight into the catalyst technology's entry in the fuel cell market, which is leading to the launching a startup company in progress. Prototypes of the catalysts and membrane electrode assemblies have been developed for evaluations by potential partners.  Another outcome is the training of young entrepreneurs in the business model development throughout the customer discovery leading to a refined business model and value proposition.  In addition, some of the Lean Startup methodologies have been incorporated into part of the teaching activities in graduate and undergraduate classrooms and in research laboratories as well.  The students and researchers have been trained in an entrepreneurial mindset that will make them more competitive in their research programs and as next-generation entrepreneurs to pursue a meaningful technology commercialization.  The industrial partnership has also provided an effective vehicle to train students and researchers for better preparation in technology commercialization in the sustainable energy market.


Last Modified: 03/03/2021
Modified by: Chuan-Jian Zhong
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This I-Corps project has aimed at training students and researchers as entrepreneurs in technology commercialization by focusing on determining the commercialization feasibility of a new catalyst technology in the market of fuel cells. Like batteries, hydrogen fuel produced from renewable solar, wind, and biomass can be stored for conversion by fuel cells. Hydrogen fuel cells represents highly efficient power with zero emission and substantial energy. There is an increasing societal need of clean and sustainable energy for reduction of greenhouse gases, which constitutes the global drive for solar and wind production of electricity, battery storage, and hydrogen economy. Automotive industry has been leading the way to push fuel cell-drive vehicles in the market. The mass commercialization of fuel cells will accelerate sustainable and clean energy sources as substitutes for fossil fuels and the reduction of transportation emissions. The global fuel cell market is predicted to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 21%. With US government emphasis on clean and sustainable energy, a huge increase of the fuel cell market size is expected alongside with the surge of solar and wind energies. Currently, the high catalyst cost and poor durability performance constitute two major areas of technical challenges for mass commercialization of fuel cells. The catalyst cost accounts for 40?50 % of the total manufacturing cost in fuel cell stacks. The pain point can be addressed by 50% or more reduction of catalysts materials in existing fuel cell systems in comparison with the bottleneck up to 25 % reduction, and enhanced durability of catalysts in fuel cell performance. Commercialization of the new catalyst technology offers an opportunity to meet the increasing demand for fuel cells by supplying high-performance catalysts for fuel cell manufacturers at low cost. This project has obtained information on the drivers in the targeted market, the value proposition specific to customer segments, the cost breakdown in the manufacturing process, the decision-making process in adopting new technologies in the manufacturing and product ecosystem. A key outcome of this project is the new insight into the catalyst technology's entry in the fuel cell market, which is leading to the launching a startup company in progress. Prototypes of the catalysts and membrane electrode assemblies have been developed for evaluations by potential partners. Another outcome is the training of young entrepreneurs in the business model development throughout the customer discovery leading to a refined business model and value proposition. In addition, some of the Lean Startup methodologies have been incorporated into part of the teaching activities in graduate and undergraduate classrooms and in research laboratories as well. The students and researchers have been trained in an entrepreneurial mindset that will make them more competitive in their research programs and as next-generation entrepreneurs to pursue a meaningful technology commercialization. The industrial partnership has also provided an effective vehicle to train students and researchers for better preparation in technology commercialization in the sustainable energy market.
